content.title: ICU Sedation Strategies
content.summary: Modern ICU sedation emphasizes light sedation, daily awakening trials (SAT), and protocolized approaches to minimize duration of mechanical ventilation, ICU-acquired weakness, and delirium. The ABCDEF bundle integrates sedation management with other evidence-based practices. Key principles include targeting RASS -1 to 0 (light sedation), using sedation scales (RASS, SAS), performing daily SAT paired with spontaneous breathing trials (SBT), and preferring non-benzodiazepine agents (propofol, dexmedetomidine) to reduce delirium risk.
key_points: Light sedation (RASS -1 to 0) preferred over deep sedation; reduces ventilator days
Daily SAT (spontaneous awakening trial) paired with SBT (spontaneous breathing trial)
Dexmedetomidine preferred for delirium prevention; propofol for shorter-term
Avoid benzodiazepines when possible - increase delirium risk
ABCDEF bundle: Assess/prevent pain, Both SAT & SBT, Choice of sedation, Delirium monitor, Early mobility, Family engagement
content.statement: ICU sedation strategies prioritize light sedation targeting RASS -1 to 0, daily awakening trials, non-benzodiazepine agents, and integration with the ABCDEF bundle to reduce ventilator days, delirium, and ICU-acquired weakness.

explanation.intuition: Think of sedation like a dimmer switch, not an on-off switch. Deep sedation was historically used for patient comfort, but we now know keeping patients lightly sedated (just calm enough for comfort and safety) gets them off the ventilator faster and with less brain fog.
explanation.key_insight: The paired SAT+SBT approach is game-changing. Stop sedation (SAT), let the patient wake up, then test if they can breathe on their own (SBT). This coordinated approach reduces ventilator days by 3+ days and mortality. Deep sedation hides readiness for extubation.
explanation.technical_details: RASS scoring: +4 combative, +3 very agitated, +2 agitated, +1 restless, 0 alert/calm, -1 drowsy, -2 light sedation, -3 moderate sedation, -4 deep sedation, -5 unarousable. SAT pass: patient follows commands. SBT: low pressure support or T-piece for 30-120 minutes. Dexmedetomidine is α2-agonist providing sedation without respiratory depression.

definitions_glossary.RASS: Richmond Agitation-Sedation Scale; -5 to +4 scale for sedation depth
definitions_glossary.SAT: Spontaneous awakening trial; daily interruption of sedation
definitions_glossary.SBT: Spontaneous breathing trial; test for extubation readiness
definitions_glossary.light_sedation: Target RASS -1 to 0; patient drowsy but arousable
definitions_glossary.deep_sedation: RASS -3 to -5; associated with worse outcomes
definitions_glossary.dexmedetomidine: Alpha-2 agonist sedative; reduces delirium; no respiratory depression
definitions_glossary.propofol: GABA agonist; rapid onset/offset; watch for propofol infusion syndrome
definitions_glossary.ABCDEF_bundle: Evidence-based ICU care bundle including sedation, delirium, mobility
definitions_glossary.delirium: Acute brain dysfunction; common in ICU; worsened by benzodiazepines
definitions_glossary.propofol_infusion_syndrome: Rare fatal complication with high-dose prolonged propofol
definitions_glossary.ICU_acquired_weakness: Muscle weakness from ICU stay; reduced by early mobility and light sedation

light_over_deep.rationale: Deep sedation prolongs ventilation, increases delirium, causes weakness
light_over_deep.evidence: Multiple RCTs show reduced ventilator days with light sedation

daily_awakening.SAT_protocol: Stop sedation daily; assess for agitation/distress

paired_SAT_SBT.concept: SAT success → proceed to SBT; coordinated by RN and RT
paired_SAT_SBT.evidence: Reduces ventilator days by 3 days; reduces 1-year mortality

RASS.documentation: Assess and document every 4 hours minimum

disadvantages: May not provide deep sedation alone
dexmedetomidine.dose: 0.2-1.5 mcg/kg/hr; no loading in most ICU patients

propofol_infusion_syndrome.prevention: Limit dose and duration; monitor triglycerides

benzodiazepines.role: Reserved for alcohol withdrawal, seizures, palliative care
benzodiazepines.avoid_when_possible: Associated with increased delirium, prolonged ventilation
benzodiazepines.PADIS_guideline: Recommends avoiding in most mechanically ventilated adults

ketamine.mechanism: NMDA antagonist with dissociative, analgesic, sedative properties
ketamine.cautions: Emergence reactions (less common with low-dose ICU use)

ABCDEF_bundle.C: Choice of analgesia and sedation (avoid benzodiazepines)
ABCDEF_bundle.evidence: Each additional bundle element increases survival likelihood

special_populations.ARDS_severe: May require deeper sedation; prone positioning may need paralysis
special_populations.traumatic_brain_injury: Balance sedation needs with neurologic assessment
special_populations.ECMO: Often require light sedation to assess neurologic status

definition.@value: Evidence-based approaches to sedation in mechanically ventilated ICU patients emphasizing light sedation and daily awakening

scopeNote.@value: Core component of ABCDEF bundle; dexmedetomidine preferred over benzodiazepines

learning_objectives: Apply RASS scale to assess sedation depth
Implement daily SAT and SBT protocols
Select appropriate sedative agent based on patient factors
Integrate sedation management into ABCDEF bundle
Recognize and prevent propofol infusion syndrome
clinical_pearls: Light sedation (RASS -1 to 0) reduces ventilator days by 2-3 days
Pair SAT with SBT daily - coordinated approach reduces mortality
Dexmedetomidine reduces delirium vs benzodiazepines - PADIS guideline recommended
Propofol infusion syndrome: watch for lactic acidosis, rhabdo with prolonged high-dose
ABCDEF bundle: each element independently improves outcomes
common_misconceptions: Deep sedation is safer for intubated patients - light sedation has better outcomes
Benzodiazepines are first-line ICU sedatives - they increase delirium
SAT and SBT should be done separately - paired approach is more effective

citations.authors: Devlin JW, Skrobik Y, Gélinas C, et al.

evidence.confidence_rationale: PADIS guidelines provide strong evidence-based recommendations
